questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a swelling on her neck for 5 months. It has gradually enlarged in size and is mildly painful. She has also had intermittent episodes of throbbing headache, sweating, and palpitations over the past 3 months. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last for 4–5 days. She does not smoke and occasionally drinks alcohol on weekends. She appears thin and pale. Her temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a firm, 3-cm swelling on the neck that moves with swallowing; there is no lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13 g/dL


Leukocyte count
9500/mm3



Platelet count
230,000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

136 mEq/L


 K+

3.5 mEq/L


 Cl-

104 mEq/L


TSH
2.3 μU/mL


 Calcitonin


300 ng/dL (Normal < 5 ng/dL)


An electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following laboratory abnormalities is most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased serum gastrin is a finding of gastrinoma tumors. Gastrinoma manifests with multiple gastrointestinal ulcers and diarrhea and may occur with MEN 1 (triad of hyperparathyroidism, pituitary adenoma, and pancreatic tumors). However, this patient most likely has MEN 2, which is not associated with gastrinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypercortisolism is a finding of Cushing syndrome. Occasionally, medullary thyroid cancers secrete corticotropin, which may lead to ectopic Cushing syndrome. Hypercortisolism may cause hypertension and neck swelling. However, this swelling is caused by fat deposition and thus is neither firm nor painful. Moreover, she lacks other classic features, such as central obesity, menstrual irregularities, or androgen excess symptoms (e.g., hirsutism, virilization).

C) INCORRECT:

Increased urinary 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid is a finding in carcinoid tumors, which very rarely occurs with MEN 1 (triad of hyperparathyroidism, pituitary adenoma, and pancreatic tumors). This patient lacks the key symptoms of carcinoid tumors, which are cutaneous flushing and severe diarrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperthyroidism is characterized by increased serum T3 and T4 levels, which can result in tachycardia, anxiety, palpitations, and diaphoresis, as well as thyroid enlargement and neck swelling. In contrast to this patient's normal TSH, primary hyperthyroidism results in a low TSH, whereas secondary hyperthyroidism results in an elevated TSH level. This patient's elevated calcitonin levels are consistent with medullary thyroid cancer, in which TSH, T3, and T4 levels are usually normal.

E) CORRECT:

Plasma metanephrines (normetanephrine and metanephrine) are a sensitive indicator of pheochromocytoma, which is characterized by intermittent hypertension, diaphoresis, headaches, and palpitations, all of which are seen in this patient. This condition is associated with the MEN 2 syndromes and about 50% of patients with MEN 2A or MEN 2B develop pheochromocytoma in addition to medullary thyroid cancer. 24-hour urinary metanephrines and catecholamines should be measured to confirm the diagnosis. Other diagnostic tests include abdominal imaging to look for an adrenal mass or genetic testing for MEN 2A or MEN 2B.

Increased metanephrines may also be seen in the case of ganglioneuromas and neuroblastomas, which can be part of MEN 2B syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient's neck swelling and elevated calcitonin suggest a diagnosis of medullary thyroid cancer. This, in combination with a condition that causes the triad of palpitations, sweating, and headaches, is consistent with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2).

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening abdominal pain over the last 3 months. He has also had recent feelings of sadness and a lack of motivation at work, where he is employed as a computer programmer. He denies suicidal thoughts. He has a history of multiple kidney stones. He has a family history of thyroid cancer in his father and uncle, who both underwent thyroidectomy before 30 years of age. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 138/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows an obese, diffusely tender abdomen but is otherwise unremarkable. Serum studies show:


Na+

141 mEq/L


K+

3.6 mEq/L


Glucose
144 mg/dL


Ca2+
12.1 mg/dL


Albumin
4.1 g/dL


Parathyroid hormone
940 pg/mL


Genetic testing shows a mutation in the RET gene. The physician refers him to an endocrine surgeon. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Measurement of midnight salivary cortisol concentration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thyroidectomy is indicated for the management of MEN 2 syndromes because almost all patients will develop medullary thyroid cancer if thyroidectomy is not performed. However, another step in management should be conducted before the patient undergoes this procedure.

B) INCORRECT:

Parathyroidectomy is indicated for the management of primary hyperparathyroidism in patients with MEN 2A. However, another step in management should be conducted before the patient undergoes this procedure.

C) CORRECT:

Increased metanephrine concentrations in the urine or plasma are indicative of pheochromocytoma, a catecholamine-secreting neuroendocrine tumor associated with MEN 2 syndromes. Pheochromocytomas usually cause paroxysms of elevated blood pressure and heart rate, but normal vitals on examination do not rule out this condition. For patients in whom a diagnosis of MEN 2 is suspected or confirmed, it is critical to evaluate for pheochromocytoma before undergoing surgical procedures (e.g., parathyroidectomy for the management of primary hyperparathyroidism or thyroidectomy to prevent the development of medullary thyroid cancer). Intraoperative catecholamine release from a pheochromocytoma can otherwise result in hemodynamic instability during the procedure.

D) INCORRECT:

An increased urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid concentration is indicative of carcinoid tumors, which can cause carcinoid syndrome. This condition can cause abdominal pain but usually also manifests with episodic diarrhea, flushing, and sweating, none of which are seen in this patient. In addition, carcinoid tumors are not associated with MEN 2 syndromes.

E) INCORRECT:

A midnight salivary cortisol test is used to screen for Cushing syndrome. Though this condition is associated with central obesity, it also typically causes moon facies, hyperglycemia, and muscle weakness, none of which are seen in this patient. In addition, Cushing syndrome is not associated with MEN 2 syndromes.

F) INCORRECT:

High serum concentrations of gastrin are indicative of gastrinoma, a type of pancreatic or duodenal tumor associated with MEN 1 rather than MEN 2 syndromes. Though MEN 1 and MEN 2 syndromes are both associated with hyperparathyroidism, this patient's family history of thyroid cancer makes an underlying diagnosis of MEN 2A more likely. In addition, MEN 1 is not associated with mutations in the RET gene.
questions.hint: This patient has primary hyperparathyroidism, which can cause abdominal pain, depressed mood, kidney stones, and increased calcium and parathyroid hormone concentrations. This condition, in combination with young age at presentation and a family history of thyroid cancer, raises suspicion for an underlying diagnosis of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN 2A), which is confirmed by the detection of a mutation of the RET gene.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with gradually worsening pain in the abdomen and right flank. The abdominal pain started 1 week ago and is accompanied by foul-smelling, lightly-colored diarrhea. The flank pain started two days ago and is now an 8 out of 10 in intensity. The pain worsens on rapid movement. She has a history of intermittent knee arthralgias. She has refractory acid reflux and antral and duodenal peptic ulcers for which she currently takes omeprazole. She appears fatigued. Her pulse is 89/min and her blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows both epigastric and right costovertebral angle tenderness. Urine dipstick shows trace red blood cells (5–10/μL). Ultrasonography shows mobile hyperechogenic structures in the right ureteropelvic junction. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A hypertensive crisis in patients with symptoms of underlying multiple endocrine neoplasia is suggestive of pheochromocytoma, a catecholamine-secreting tumor. Catecholamines (e.g., norepinephrine) can lead to sudden rises in blood pressure. While pheochromocytoma can occur in both MEN 2A and MEN 2B, it is not associated with MEN 1.

B) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous flushing in individuals with abdominal pain and diarrhea should raise suspicion of carcinoid syndrome, which is most commonly caused by carcinoid tumors of the small intestine. Although carcinoid tumors are associated with MEN 1, they are usually nonfunctioning gastric, bronchial, or thymic tumors. Also, they only occur in ∼ 10–15% of patients with MEN 1; a different finding is much more likely in this woman.

C) INCORRECT:

Intestinal ganglioneuromas are usually an incidental finding detected on imaging (e.g., CT). While the tumors are mostly asymptomatic, they can cause symptoms due to compression of surrounding structures (e.g., abdominal pain) or secretion of hormones (e.g., VIP-induced diarrhea). However, intestinal ganglioneuromas are most commonly seen in patients with MEN 2B, not MEN 1.

D) CORRECT:

This patient presents with symptoms of MEN 1, a syndrome that predisposes to a range of conditions, including Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Symptoms of a kidney stone, intermittent arthralgias, abdominal pain, and fatigue further suggest primary hyperparathyroidism (pHPT), which occurs in ∼ 90% of individuals with MEN 1. Increased parathyroid hormone levels and hypercalcemia are the main diagnostic features of pHPT, and the underlying cause of this patient's kidney stone.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis in a patient with MEN 1 is suggestive of a serotonin-secreting carcinoid tumor. Increased serotonin levels can lead to cardiac fibrosis and could also be the cause of this patient's abdominal cramps and diarrhea. However, carcinoid tumors only occur in ∼ 10–15% of patients with MEN 1 and are mostly nonfunctioning; a different finding is much more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

QT prolongation can be caused by a number of conditions, of which hypocalcemia is a common one. Almost all patients with MEN 2A and MEN 2B develop medullary thyroid carcinoma, which produces calcitonin and thereby induces hypocalcemia. Individuals with MEN 1, however, do not commonly develop medullary thyroid cancer or hypocalcemia.
questions.hint: This patient has refractory peptic ulcer disease with multiple ulcerations and steatorrhea (foul-smelling, lightly-colored stools). These features suggest Zollinger-Ellison syndrome or gastrinoma, which should raise suspicion for multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1). The acute-onset severe flank pain, microhematuria on dipstick, and hyperechoic mass on ultrasonography further indicate a kidney stone.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the physician because of fatigue, nausea, joint pain, and mild flank pain for 2 months. She has refractory acid reflux and antral and duodenal peptic ulcers for which she takes omeprazole. She also has chronic, foul-smelling, light-colored diarrhea. Five years ago she was successfully treated for infertility with bromocriptine. She reports recently feeling sad and unmotivated at work. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is moderately distended and diffusely tender to palpation. There is mild costovertebral angle tenderness. Her serum calcium concentration is 12 mg/dL, phosphorus concentration is 2 mg/dL, and parathyroid hormone level is 400 pg/mL. Abdominal ultrasound shows mobile echogenic foci with acoustic shadowing in her ureteropelvic junctions bilaterally. A mutation in which of the following genes is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the NF2 gene is the underlying cause of neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF type 2). NF type 2 typically manifests around the age of 20 with symptoms of bilateral acoustic neuromas (hearing deficit, vertigo), juvenile cataracts (visual impairment), and meningiomas (mass effect on the brain, e.g., paraparesis, headache, seizures), which this patient has no evidence of. Furthermore, this patient shows signs of hyperparathyroidism, prolactinoma, and gastrinoma, which are not consistent with NF type 2.

B) INCORRECT:

Mutation of the VHL gene causes von Hippel-Lindau disease, which is associated with renal cell carcinoma (RCC). One of the paraneoplastic syndromes of RCC is the secretion of parathyroid hormone-related protein, which mimics the effects of PTH and causes hyperparathyroidism. However, this patient lacks other distinguishing features of VHL such as cavernous hemangiomas of the skin or mucosa and hemangioblastomas of the retina or cerebellum. Furthermore, this patient shows signs of prolactinoma and gastrinoma, which is not consistent with von Hippel-Lindau disease.

C) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the proto-oncogene c-Kit can cause gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs), which are usually asymptomatic but can cause peptic ulcers as seen in this patient. However, GISTs would not manifest with hyperparathyroidism or prolactinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Pathologic activation of the RET gene leads to multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2). Hyperparathyroidism may be present in the MEN 2A subtype, but MEN 2 variants classically manifest with medullary thyroid carcinoma and pheochromocytoma. Furthermore, this patient shows signs of prolactinoma and gastrinoma, which is not consistent with MEN 2.

E) CORRECT:

Altered expression of the tumor suppressor protein menin due to a mutation in the MEN1 gene leads to MEN 1 syndrome, which is characterized by a predisposition to tumors of the 3 P's: anterior pituitary gland (often prolactinoma), parathyroid gland (leading to hyperparathyroidism), and pancreas (e.g., gastrinoma, insulinoma).

Management of MEN 1 syndrome often involves surgical excision of individual tumors (e.g., parathyroidectomy).
questions.hint: This patient's flank pain with evidence of kidney stones on ultrasound, joint pain, nausea, and depressed mood are consistent with the “stones, bones, abdominal groans, and psychiatric overtones” of hypercalcemia. Her laboratory values confirm primary hyperparathyroidism as a cause. That her infertility was treated successfully with bromocriptine suggests prolactinoma, and her refractory peptic ulcer disease with multiple ulcerations and steatorrhea raises suspicion for gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of difficulty swallowing that has worsened over the past year. He also reports some hoarseness and generalized bone, muscle, and joint pain. During the past six months, he has had progressive constipation and two episodes of kidney stones. He also reports recurrent episodes of throbbing headaches, diaphoresis, and palpitations. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination and an ECG show no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show calcium concentration of 12 mg/dL, phosphorus concentration of 2 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase concentration of 130 U/L, and calcitonin concentration of 11 pg/mL (N < 8.8). Ultrasonography of the neck shows hypoechoic thyroid lesions with irregular margins and microcalcifications. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neurofibromatosis type 1 is caused by mutations in the NF1 gene. This gene mutation is associated with pheochromocytoma, which should be suspected based on this patient's recurrent episodes of throbbing headaches, diaphoresis, and heart palpitations. However, additional signs of neurofibromatosis type 1 are missing (e.g., café au lait spots, cutaneous neurofibromas, and Lisch nodules).
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

B) INCORRECT:

Exposure to ionizing radiation during childhood is associated with the formation of papillary thyroid carcinoma. This patient's dysphagia and ultrasonography findings of hypoechoic lesions and microcalcifications are all consistent with advanced papillary thyroid carcinoma. However, this patient has several other findings that can not be explained by papillary thyroid carcinoma (i.e., throbbing headaches, diaphoresis, heart palpitations, constipation, kidney stones, elevated calcitonin and calcium).

C) INCORRECT:

Von Hippel-Lindau disease is caused by deletion of the VHL gene and is characterized by hemangioblastomas, bilateral renal cell carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and renal cysts. This patient's recurrent episodes of throbbing headaches, diaphoresis, and heart palpitations are suspicious for pheochromocytoma, but there are no other signs of Von Hippel-Lindau disease.

D) CORRECT:

Multiple endocrine neoplasia 2A and 2B (MEN 2A and MEN 2B) are caused by a germline mutation and lead to altered expression of the RET proto-oncogene. This patient's features of medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and primary hyperparathyroidism strongly suggest MEN 2A. Since MEN 2A and B are caused by an autosomal dominant gene mutation, all family members of this patient should be screened for the presence of the mutated gene.

E) INCORRECT:

Altered menin protein expression is seen in MEN 1, which is also associated with primary hyperparathyroidism. However, other common features of MEN 1, such as signs of carcinoid tumor, pituitary adenoma, or endocrine pancreatic tumors (i.e. gastrinoma or insulinoma), are not seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of medullary thyroid carcinoma (dysphagia, hoarseness, elevated calcitonin, irregular margins, and microcalcifications on neck ultrasonography), pheochromocytoma (throbbing headaches, diaphoresis, heart palpitations), and primary hyperparathyroidism (constipation, recurrent kidney stones, elevated calcium and ALP, decreased phosphorus). These features are suggestive of multiple endocrine neoplasia 2A (MEN 2A).

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician for a 2-month history of fatigue, intermittent left-sided flank pain, and diffuse extremity pain. She was treated for a prolactinoma 5 years ago and has had recurrent antral and duodenal peptic ulcers despite medical therapy. Her only medication is omeprazole. Physical examination shows a moderately distended abdomen that is diffusely tender to palpation. There is mild left-sided costovertebral angle tenderness. Serum studies show a calcium concentration of 12 mg/dL, phosphorus concentration of 2 mg/dL, and parathyroid hormone level of 426 pg/mL. An ultrasound of the abdomen shows multiple kidney stones in the left ureteropelvic junction. This patient is most likely to have which of the following protein abnormalities?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pathologic inactivation of the RET gene causes Hirschsprung disease, a congenital abnormality of the colon that results in bilious emesis, abdominal distention, and failure to pass meconium. It is not associated with the parathyroid, pituitary, and pancreatic abnormalities seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Altered merlin expression is the hallmark of neurofibromatosis type 2, which is characterized by bilateral acoustic neuromas, juvenile cataracts, and meningiomas. NF2 would not explain the parathyroid, pancreatic, and pituitary abnormalities seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Altered menin protein function resulting from a mutation in the MEN1 gene is seen in multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1. MEN1 is characterized by the 3 P's: pituitary tumors (prolactinoma), parathyroid gland tumors (resulting in primary hyperparathyroidism), and pancreatic tumors (such as gastrinoma or insulinoma). MEN1 is also associated with angiofibromas and meningiomas.

D) INCORRECT:

VHL gene mutations can result in von Hippel-Lindau disease, which is characterized by bilateral renal cell carcinoma (RCC). RCC may cause secretion of parathyroid hormone-related protein, which can also lead to symptoms of hyperparathyroidism (as seen in this patient). However, this patient lacks other distinguishing features of VHL, such as angiomatosis, pheochromocytomas, and hemangioblastomas.

E) INCORRECT:

Proto-oncogene c-Kit is a cytokine receptor oncogene that can be found in gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST), as well as mastocytomas, seminomas, embryonal carcinomas, and myeloid leukemias. However, none of these malignancies would explain this patient's constellation of parathyroid, pituitary, and pancreatic abnormalities.
questions.hint: This patient has evidence of hyperparathyroidism (hypercalcemia, elevated PTH level) and a history of recurrent ulcers, which suggests Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. The constellation of parathyroid, pituitary, and pancreatic disease should raise suspicion for multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1).

questions.text:
A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening abdominal pain, an inability to concentrate at work, and a general lack of motivation over the past several months. He has a history of spontaneous passage of two kidney stones. His father and uncle underwent thyroidectomy before the age of 35 for thyroid cancer. Physical examination shows diffuse tenderness over the abdomen. Serum studies show:


Na+

142 mEq/L


K+

3.7 mEq/L


Glucose (fasting)
83 mg/dL


Ca2+

12.3 mg/dL


Albumin
4.1 g/dL


Parathyroid hormone
350 pg/mL


Further evaluation is most likely to show elevated levels of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased levels of serum gastrin are seen in gastrinoma, a type of pancreatic or duodenal tumor often seen in MEN 1 syndrome. While this patient does have hyperparathyroidism, which is a feature of MEN 1 syndrome, his family history of thyroid cancer is suggestive of MEN 2A.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased levels of prolactin are seen in lactotrophic pituitary adenomas (prolactinomas). This is the most common type of pituitary adenoma in adults and in patients with MEN 1 syndrome. While this patient does have hyperparathyroidism, which is a feature of MEN 1, his family history of thyroid cancer is suggestive of MEN 2A.

C) INCORRECT:

An increased serum aldosterone to renin ratio is seen in patients with primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn syndrome). Excess aldosterone production can result in constantly elevated blood pressure, fatigue, and muscle cramping due to electrolyte abnormalities, specifically hypokalemia, none of which are seen in this patient. Conn syndrome is not associated with MEN 2A.

D) INCORRECT:

Midnight salivary cortisol is a screening test for Cushing syndrome. This disorder classically presents with central obesity, moon facies, elevated serum glucose, and/or proximal muscle weakness, none of which are seen here. Cushing syndrome is not associated with MEN 2A.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased levels of serotonin (5-HT) metabolites such as 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) in the urine are seen in carcinoid tumors, a type of neuroendocrine cancer that often develops in the gastrointestinal tract. A carcinoid tumor can lead to carcinoid syndrome if it metastasizes to the liver. Carcinoid syndrome classically manifests with watery diarrhea, episodic cutaneous flushing, and sweating, which are not seen in this patient. Carcinoid tumors are not associated with MEN 2A.

Carcinoid tumors are seen in 10–15% of patients with MEN 1 syndrome. Most of these tumors are nonfunctioning and therefore do not cause typical carcinoid syndrome.

F) CORRECT:

Increased levels of catecholamine metabolites such as metanephrines in the urine or serum are diagnostic of pheochromocytoma, a catecholamine-secreting neuroendocrine tumor typically located in the adrenal medulla. Pheochromocytomas may be a sign of genetic syndromes such as MEN 2A and MEN 2B due to an autosomal dominant mutation of the RET gene.

In patients with MEN 2 syndromes, prophylactic thyroidectomy is generally indicated because almost all patients will develop medullary thyroid cancer.
questions.hint: A young patient with primary hyperparathyroidism (difficulty concentrating, lethargy, recurrent kidney stones, elevated PTH levels, and increased serum calcium) and a family history of thyroid cancer should raise suspicion for multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN 2A) syndrome.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of a painless lump on his neck. Two years ago, he underwent surgery for treatment-resistant hypertension, episodic headaches, and palpitations. Physical examination shows a firm, irregular swelling on the right side of the neck. Ultrasonography of the thyroid gland shows a 2-cm nodule with irregular margins and microcalcifications in the right thyroid lobe. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show increased serum concentration of which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a malignant neoplasm of the parafollicular cells (C cells) that often arises sporadically but is also associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A and type 2B (MEN2). Since parafollicular cells produce the hormone calcitonin, increased serum calcitonin would be expected. Measuring the serum calcitonin concentration is helpful to support the diagnosis of medullary thyroid carcinoma and is also used to monitor for residual disease or recurrence after thyroidectomy.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased serum gastrin would be seen in gastrinoma, which is a feature of MEN1, not MEN2. MEN1 would also manifest with primary hyperparathyroidism and/or pituitary adenomas, not with pheochromocytoma. Furthermore, gastrinomas are located mainly in the duodenum or pancreas and would therefore neither cause a swelling on the right side of the neck nor a nodule in the thyroid lobe. Finally, symptoms of gastrinoma such as treatment-resistant peptic ulcer disease and diarrhea are not seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased serum metanephrines would be seen in pheochromocytoma, which is a feature of MEN2. However, the patient was already operated on for a pheochromocytoma, and the recent findings are consistent with medullary thyroid carcinoma, which would not result in an increase in serum metanephrines.

D) INCORRECT:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma does not lead to increased serum TSH. Increased serum TSH can be seen in primary hypothyroidism or central hyperthyroidism. However, this patient has no symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., weight gain, constipation, fatigue) or hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, diarrhea, restlessness). Also, MEN2 is not commonly associated with dysfunction of the thyroid gland.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased serum PTH would indicate hyperparathyroidism, which is a feature of MEN2 A in 20–30% of cases. However, the patient shows no symptoms of hyperparathyroidism (e.g., nephrolithiasis, bone, muscle, and joint pain, peptic ulcer disease, or depression). Additionally, a firm, irregular thyroid nodule is more suggestive of a malignancy of the thyroid gland, which does not increase serum PTH.
questions.hint: This patient likely has a history of pheochromocytoma (treatment-resistant hypertension, episodic headaches, palpitations) that was treated with adrenalectomy. His painless, irregular thyroid nodule should raise concern for medullary thyroid carcinoma as a feature of MEN2 syndrome.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the physician for a 1-week history of a painless swelling on the right side of his neck that he noticed while showering. He is 203 cm (6 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Physical examination shows long, thin fingers and an increased arm-length to body-height ratio. Examination of the neck shows a single 2-cm firm nodule. Ultrasonography of the neck shows a hypoechoic thyroid lesion with irregular margins. A core needle biopsy of the thyroid lesion shows sheets of polygonal cells surrounded by Congo red-stained amorphous tissue. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gastric ulcers secondary to a gastrinoma are a possible manifestation of MEN 1. This autosomal-dominant syndrome is caused by a mutated menin protein and can further present with primary hyperparathyroidism (∼ 90% of cases), carcinoid tumors, pituitary tumors, and other endocrine pancreatic tumors, none of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, MEN 1 is not associated with medullary thyroid cancer or a marfanoid habitus, and gastrinomas are not a manifestation of MEN 2B.

B) CORRECT:

Mucosal neuromas, often involving the lips and tongue, are characteristic manifestations of MEN 2B. This autosomal-dominant syndrome is caused by a mutated RET proto-oncogene that almost always leads to the development of medullary thyroid cancer at a young age. Further common manifestations of MEN 2B include pheochromocytoma and intestinal ganglioneuromatosis. The next step in management in this patient is measurement of urine metanephrines to rule out pheochromocytoma, followed by thyroidectomy with cervical lymph node dissection. As opposed to MEN 2A, which is caused by a mutation in the same gene, MEN 2B is not associated with primary hyperparathyroidism.

C) INCORRECT:

Recurrent hypoglycemia secondary to an insulinoma is a possible manifestation of MEN 1. This autosomal-dominant syndrome is caused by a mutated menin protein and can further present with primary hyperparathyroidism (∼ 90% of cases), carcinoid tumors, pituitary tumors, and other endocrine pancreatic tumors, none of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, MEN 1 is not associated with medullary thyroid cancer or a marfanoid habitus, and insulinomas are not a manifestation of MEN 2B.

D) INCORRECT:

Kidney stones due to primary hyperparathyroidism are a possible manifestation of MEN 2A. Virtually all patients with MEN 2A develop medullary thyroid cancer; however, this condition is not associated with the marfanoid habitus seen in this patient. Although MEN 2A and MEN 2B are caused by a mutation in the same proto-oncogene, the latter is not associated with primary hyperparathyroidism.

E) INCORRECT:

Common causes of episodic hypotension include autonomic dysfunction, volume depletion, and certain medications (e.g, antidepressants, beta blockers). However, MEN 2B is not known to cause hypotensive events. In contrast, MEN 2B commonly manifests with pheochromocytoma, which is characterized by episodic hypertension, paroxysmal headaches, diaphoresis, heart palpitations, and pallor.

F) INCORRECT:

Breast enlargement (i.e., gynecomastia) due to a prolactinoma is a possible manifestation of MEN 1. This autosomal-dominant syndrome is caused by a mutated menin protein and can further present with primary hyperparathyroidism (∼ 90% of cases), endocrine pancreatic tumors, carcinoid tumors, and other pituitary tumors, none of which are present in this patient. Furthermore, MEN 1 is not associated with medullary thyroid cancer or a marfanoid habitus, and prolactinomas are not a manifestation of MEN 2B.
questions.hint: This patient's biopsy findings are diagnostic of medullary thyroid cancer. In addition, he presents with a marfanoid habitus (tall stature, long, slender fingers, and increased arm-length to body-height ratio), which strongly suggests multiple endocrine neoplasia 2B (MEN 2B).

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: MRI of the sella with contrast
CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

As patients with MEN 2 have a high risk of developing medullary thyroid carcinoma, management is required at this point.

B) INCORRECT:

MRI of the sella with IV contrast is the gold standard diagnostic test for pituitary adenoma, which is common in individuals with MEN 1 but not in those with MEN 2.

C) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast is the preferred imaging for pheochromocytoma, which is common in patients with MEN 2. Pheochromocytoma should be ruled out or treated in patients with MEN 2 before surgery since the intraoperative release of catecholamines from a pheochromocytoma can lead to hemodynamic instability during the procedure. A plasma metanephrine test is highly sensitive for a pheochromocytoma. Normal plasma levels of free metanephrines reliably rule out pheochromocytoma and exclude the need for further diagnostics to rule out this tumor.

D) INCORRECT:

Measurement of 24-hour urinary calcium is indicated in patients with confirmed primary hyperparathyroidism to evaluate the risk of nephrocalcinosis and nephrolithiasis and to exclude familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia. While primary hyperparathyroidism is common in individuals with MEN 2, this patient's calcium level is normal, excluding hyperparathyroidism and the need for further evaluation.

E) CORRECT:

Nearly all patients with MEN 2 develop medullary thyroid cancer, often early in life. Prophylactic thyroidectomy is recommended as soon as possible in all patients with known RET mutations. Other conditions associated with MEN 2 include pheochromocytoma, primary hyperparathyroidism in MEN 2A subtype, and neurinomas and Marfanoid habitus in MEN 2B subtype. Pheochromocytoma should be ruled out (with a plasma metanephrine test) or treated before thyroid surgery since the intraoperative release of catecholamines from a pheochromocytoma can lead to hemodynamic instability during the procedure. Parathyroidectomy is indicated in patients with symptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism.
questions.hint: A positive RET gene mutation in a patient with a family history of medullary thyroid cancer is consistent with a diagnosis of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2).

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man presents with a palpable mass in his neck. He is otherwise asymptomatic. He notes that his older sister had medullary thyroid cancer at age 25 and underwent thyroidectomy.
On examination, his blood pressure is 138/86 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 82 beats per minute. A palpable, smooth, 2-cm mass in the lower part of his left thyroid moves with swallowing.
Ultrasound of the neck reveals a 2-cm thyroid nodule with no evidence of abnormal lymph nodes. Fine-needle aspiration reveals cytologic features of medullary thyroid carcinoma, and elective thyroidectomy is planned.
Preoperative laboratory testing shows mildly elevated levels of calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen. Genetic testing shows a pathogenic variant in the RET gene.
Which one of the following screening tests is appropriate before this patient safely undergoes thyroidectomy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Medullary thyroid cancers (MTCs) account for approximately 4% of all thyroid cancers in the United States. Most are sporadic, but about 25% occur in people who carry pathogenic variants in the RET gene; all patients with MTC should therefore undergo genetic testing for such variants.

Pathogenic variants in the RET gene can manifest as an autosomal dominant inherited syndrome of multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN 2A or 2B) or as familial MTC. The most common clinical subtype of MEN2 is type 2A, with typical onset in the third or fourth decade of life; this syndrome is characterized by the triad of MTC, pheochromocytoma, and primary hyperparathyroidism.

Approximately 40% of patients with MEN 2A or 2B have pheochromocytoma, which may go undiagnosed. Hypertension is the only presenting symptom in half of these patients. Given that surgery can induce a hypertensive crisis in a patient with a pheochromocytoma, clinicians should take care to exclude this diagnosis before proceeding with elective thyroidectomy in patients with MTC who carry pathogenic variants in the RET gene; the presence of a pheochromocytoma would significantly alter preoperative planning. Plasma free-metanephrine testing is the most convenient and sensitive approach to exclude a pheochromocytoma.

Key learning point: Patients with medullary thyroid cancer who carry a pathogenic variant in the RET gene should have preoperative testing with plasma free-metanephrine testing.

B) INCORRECT:

Pituitary adenomas and abnormalities are neither features of MEN2 nor associated with medullary thyroid cancer. Pituitary adenomas are associated with MEN1. Therefore, a prolactin level is not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Pituitary adenomas and abnormalities are neither features of MEN2 nor associated with medullary thyroid cancer. Pituitary adenomas are associated with MEN1. Therefore, a pituitary MRI is not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

MEN1 is associated with pancreatic neuroendocrine neoplasia, but MEN2 is not. Measuring gastrin levels is not indicated in patients with medullary thyroid cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

An echocardiogram is not indicated in the perioperative evaluation of a patient with features of possible MEN2.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman comes to the office because of a swelling on her neck for 5 months. It has gradually enlarged in size and is mildly painful. She has also had intermittent episodes of throbbing headache, sweating, and palpitations over the past 3 months. She appears thin and pale. Her temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a firm, 3-cm swelling on the neck that moves with swallowing; there is no lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:


Na+

136 mEq/L


K+

3.5 mEq/L


Cl-

104 mEq/L


TSH
2.3 μU/mL


Calcitonin

300 ng/dL (Normal < 5 ng/dL)


An electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following laboratory abnormalities is most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased serum gastrin is a finding of gastrinoma tumors. Gastrinoma manifests with multiple gastrointestinal ulcers and diarrhea and may occur with MEN 1 (triad of hyperparathyroidism, pituitary adenoma, and pancreatic tumors). However, this patient most likely has MEN 2, which is not associated with gastrinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypercortisolism is a finding of Cushing syndrome. Occasionally, medullary thyroid cancers secrete corticotropin, which may lead to ectopic Cushing syndrome. Hypercortisolism may cause hypertension and neck swelling. However, this swelling is caused by fat deposition and thus is neither firm nor painful. Moreover, she lacks other classic features, such as central obesity, menstrual irregularities, or androgen excess symptoms (e.g., hirsutism, virilization).

C) INCORRECT:

Increased urinary 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid is a finding in carcinoid tumors, which very rarely occurs with MEN 1 (triad of hyperparathyroidism, pituitary adenoma, and pancreatic tumors). This patient lacks the key symptoms of carcinoid tumors, which are cutaneous flushing and severe diarrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperthyroidism is characterized by increased serum T3 and T4 levels, which can result in tachycardia, anxiety, palpitations, and diaphoresis, as well as thyroid enlargement and neck swelling. In contrast to this patient's normal TSH, primary hyperthyroidism results in a low TSH, whereas secondary hyperthyroidism results in an elevated TSH level. This patient's elevated calcitonin levels are consistent with medullary thyroid cancer, in which TSH, T3, and T4 levels are usually normal.

E) CORRECT:

Plasma metanephrines (normetanephrine and metanephrine) are a sensitive indicator of pheochromocytoma, which is characterized by intermittent hypertension, diaphoresis, headaches, and palpitations, all of which are seen in this patient. This condition is associated with the MEN 2 syndromes and about 50% of patients with MEN 2A or MEN 2B develop pheochromocytoma in addition to medullary thyroid cancer. 24-hour urinary metanephrines and catecholamines should be measured to confirm the diagnosis. Other diagnostic tests include abdominal imaging to look for an adrenal mass or genetic testing for MEN 2A or MEN 2B.

Increased metanephrines may also be seen in the case of ganglioneuromas and neuroblastomas, which can be part of MEN 2B syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient's neck swelling and elevated calcitonin suggest a diagnosis of medullary thyroid cancer. This, in combination with a condition that causes the triad of palpitations, sweating, and headaches, is consistent with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2).

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the office for a 1-week history of a painless swelling on the right side of his neck that he noticed while showering. He is 203 cm (6 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Physical examination shows long, thin fingers and an increased arm-length to body-height ratio. Examination of the neck shows a single 2-cm firm nodule. Ultrasonography of the neck shows a hypoechoic thyroid lesion with irregular margins. A core needle biopsy of the thyroid lesion shows sheets of polygonal cells surrounded by Congo red-stained amorphous tissue. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gastric ulcers secondary to a gastrinoma are a possible manifestation of MEN 1. This autosomal-dominant syndrome is caused by a mutated menin protein and can further present with primary hyperparathyroidism (∼ 90% of cases), carcinoid tumors, pituitary tumors, and other endocrine pancreatic tumors, none of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, MEN 1 is not associated with medullary thyroid cancer or a marfanoid habitus, and gastrinomas are not a manifestation of MEN 2B.

B) CORRECT:

Mucosal neuromas, often involving the lips and tongue, are characteristic manifestations of MEN 2B. This autosomal-dominant syndrome is caused by a mutated RET proto-oncogene that almost always leads to the development of medullary thyroid cancer at a young age. Further common manifestations of MEN 2B include pheochromocytoma and intestinal ganglioneuromatosis. The next step in management in this patient is measurement of urine metanephrines to rule out pheochromocytoma, followed by thyroidectomy with cervical lymph node dissection. As opposed to MEN 2A, which is caused by a mutation in the same gene, MEN 2B is not associated with primary hyperparathyroidism.

C) INCORRECT:

Recurrent hypoglycemia secondary to an insulinoma is a possible manifestation of MEN 1. This autosomal-dominant syndrome is caused by a mutated menin protein and can further present with primary hyperparathyroidism (∼ 90% of cases), carcinoid tumors, pituitary tumors, and other endocrine pancreatic tumors, none of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, MEN 1 is not associated with medullary thyroid cancer or a marfanoid habitus, and insulinomas are not a manifestation of MEN 2B.

D) INCORRECT:

Common causes of episodic hypotension include autonomic dysfunction, volume depletion, and certain medications (e.g, antidepressants, beta blockers). However, MEN 2B is not known to cause hypotensive events. In contrast, MEN 2B commonly manifests with pheochromocytoma, which is characterized by episodic hypertension, paroxysmal headaches, diaphoresis, heart palpitations, and pallor.

E) INCORRECT:

Breast enlargement (i.e., gynecomastia) due to a prolactinoma is a possible manifestation of MEN 1. This autosomal-dominant syndrome is caused by a mutated menin protein and can further present with primary hyperparathyroidism (∼ 90% of cases), endocrine pancreatic tumors, carcinoid tumors, and other pituitary tumors, none of which are present in this patient. Furthermore, MEN 1 is not associated with medullary thyroid cancer or a marfanoid habitus, and prolactinomas are not a manifestation of MEN 2B.
questions.hint: This patient's biopsy findings are diagnostic of medullary thyroid cancer. In addition, he presents with a marfanoid habitus (tall stature, long, slender fingers, and increased arm-length to body-height ratio), which strongly suggests multiple endocrine neoplasia 2B (MEN 2B).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of difficulty swallowing that has worsened over the past year. He also reports some hoarseness and generalized bone, muscle, and joint pain. During the past six months, he has had progressive constipation and two episodes of kidney stones. He also reports recurrent episodes of throbbing headaches, diaphoresis, and palpitations. Laboratory studies show calcium concentration of 12 mg/dL, phosphorus concentration of 2 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase concentration of 130 U/L, and calcitonin concentration of 11 pg/mL (N < 8.8). Ultrasonography of the neck shows hypoechoic thyroid lesions with irregular margins and microcalcifications. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neurofibromatosis type 1 is caused by mutations in the NF1 gene. This gene mutation is associated with pheochromocytoma, which should be suspected based on this patient's recurrent episodes of throbbing headaches, diaphoresis, and heart palpitations. However, additional signs of neurofibromatosis type 1 are missing (e.g., café au lait spots, cutaneous neurofibromas, and Lisch nodules).
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.

B) INCORRECT:

Exposure to ionizing radiation during childhood is associated with the formation of papillary thyroid carcinoma. This patient's dysphagia and ultrasonography findings of hypoechoic lesions and microcalcifications are all consistent with advanced papillary thyroid carcinoma. However, this patient has several other findings that can not be explained by papillary thyroid carcinoma (i.e., throbbing headaches, diaphoresis, heart palpitations, constipation, kidney stones, elevated calcitonin and calcium).

C) INCORRECT:

Von Hippel-Lindau disease is caused by deletion of the VHL gene and is characterized by hemangioblastomas, bilateral renal cell carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and renal cysts. This patient's recurrent episodes of throbbing headaches, diaphoresis, and heart palpitations are suspicious for pheochromocytoma, but there are no other signs of Von Hippel-Lindau disease.

D) CORRECT:

Multiple endocrine neoplasia 2A and 2B (MEN 2A and MEN 2B) are caused by a germline mutation and lead to altered expression of the RET proto-oncogene. This patient's features of medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and primary hyperparathyroidism strongly suggest MEN 2A. Since MEN 2A and B are caused by an autosomal dominant gene mutation, all family members of this patient should be screened for the presence of the mutated gene.

E) INCORRECT:

Altered menin protein expression is seen in MEN 1, which is also associated with primary hyperparathyroidism. However, other common features of MEN 1, such as signs of carcinoid tumor, pituitary adenoma, or endocrine pancreatic tumors (i.e. gastrinoma or insulinoma), are not seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of medullary thyroid carcinoma (dysphagia, hoarseness, elevated calcitonin, irregular margins, and microcalcifications on neck ultrasonography), pheochromocytoma (throbbing headaches, diaphoresis, heart palpitations), and primary hyperparathyroidism (constipation, recurrent kidney stones, elevated calcium and ALP, decreased phosphorus). These features are suggestive of multiple endocrine neoplasia 2A (MEN 2A).

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the office because of fatigue, nausea, joint pain, low mood, and mild flank pain for 2 months. She has refractory acid reflux and antral and duodenal peptic ulcers for which she takes omeprazole. She also has chronic, foul-smelling, light-colored diarrhea. Five years ago she was successfully treated for infertility with bromocriptine. The abdomen is moderately distended and diffusely tender to palpation. There is mild costovertebral angle tenderness. Her serum calcium concentration is 12 mg/dL, phosphorus concentration is 2 mg/dL, and parathyroid hormone level is 400 pg/mL. Abdominal ultrasound shows mobile echogenic foci with acoustic shadowing in her ureteropelvic junctions bilaterally. A mutation in which of the following genes is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the NF2 gene is the underlying cause of neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF type 2). NF type 2 typically manifests around the age of 20 with symptoms of bilateral acoustic neuromas (hearing deficit, vertigo), juvenile cataracts (visual impairment), and meningiomas (mass effect on the brain, e.g., paraparesis, headache, seizures), which this patient has no evidence of. Furthermore, this patient shows signs of hyperparathyroidism, prolactinoma, and gastrinoma, which are not consistent with NF type 2.

B) INCORRECT:

Mutation of the VHL gene causes von Hippel-Lindau disease, which is associated with renal cell carcinoma (RCC). One of the paraneoplastic syndromes of RCC is the secretion of parathyroid hormone-related protein, which mimics the effects of PTH and causes hyperparathyroidism. However, this patient lacks other distinguishing features of VHL such as cavernous hemangiomas of the skin or mucosa and hemangioblastomas of the retina or cerebellum. Furthermore, this patient shows signs of prolactinoma and gastrinoma, which is not consistent with von Hippel-Lindau disease.

C) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the proto-oncogene c-Kit can cause gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs), which are usually asymptomatic but can cause peptic ulcers as seen in this patient. However, GISTs would not manifest with hyperparathyroidism or prolactinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Pathologic activation of the RET gene leads to multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2). Hyperparathyroidism may be present in the MEN 2A subtype, but MEN 2 variants classically manifest with medullary thyroid carcinoma and pheochromocytoma. Furthermore, this patient shows signs of prolactinoma and gastrinoma, which is not consistent with MEN 2.

E) CORRECT:

Altered expression of the tumor suppressor protein menin due to a mutation in the MEN1 gene leads to MEN 1 syndrome, which is characterized by a predisposition to tumors of the 3 P's: anterior pituitary gland (often prolactinoma), parathyroid gland (leading to hyperparathyroidism), and pancreas (e.g., gastrinoma, insulinoma).

Management of MEN 1 syndrome often involves surgical excision of individual tumors (e.g., parathyroidectomy).
questions.hint: This patient's flank pain with evidence of kidney stones on ultrasound, joint pain, nausea, and depressed mood are consistent with the “stones, bones, abdominal groans, and psychiatric overtones” of hypercalcemia. Her laboratory values confirm primary hyperparathyroidism as a cause. That her infertility was treated successfully with bromocriptine suggests prolactinoma, and her refractory peptic ulcer disease with multiple ulcerations and steatorrhea raises suspicion for gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome).

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the office because of a 1-month history of a painless lump on his neck. Two years ago, he underwent adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma. Physical examination shows a firm, irregular swelling on the right side of the neck. Ultrasonography of the thyroid gland shows a 2-cm nodule with irregular margins and microcalcifications in the right thyroid lobe. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show increased serum concentration of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a malignant neoplasm of the parafollicular cells (C cells) that often arises sporadically but is also associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A and type 2B (MEN2). Since parafollicular cells produce the hormone calcitonin, increased serum calcitonin would be expected. Measuring the serum calcitonin concentration is helpful to support the diagnosis of medullary thyroid carcinoma and is also used to monitor for residual disease or recurrence after thyroidectomy.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased serum gastrin would be seen in gastrinoma, which is a feature of MEN1, not MEN2. MEN1 would also manifest with primary hyperparathyroidism and/or pituitary adenomas, not with pheochromocytoma. Furthermore, gastrinomas are located mainly in the duodenum or pancreas and would therefore neither cause a swelling on the right side of the neck nor a nodule in the thyroid lobe. Finally, symptoms of gastrinoma such as treatment-resistant peptic ulcer disease and diarrhea are not seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased serum metanephrines would be seen in pheochromocytoma, which is a feature of MEN2. However, the patient was already operated on for a pheochromocytoma, and the recent findings are consistent with medullary thyroid carcinoma, which would not result in an increase in serum metanephrines.

D) INCORRECT:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma does not lead to increased serum TSH. Increased serum TSH can be seen in primary hypothyroidism or central hyperthyroidism. However, this patient has no symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., weight gain, constipation, fatigue) or hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, diarrhea, restlessness). Also, MEN2 is not commonly associated with dysfunction of the thyroid gland.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased serum PTH would indicate hyperparathyroidism, which is a feature of MEN2 A in 20–30% of cases. However, the patient shows no symptoms of hyperparathyroidism (e.g., nephrolithiasis, bone, muscle, and joint pain, peptic ulcer disease, or depression). Additionally, a firm, irregular thyroid nodule is more suggestive of a malignancy of the thyroid gland, which does not increase serum PTH.
questions.hint: His painless, irregular thyroid nodule should raise concern for medullary thyroid carcinoma as a feature of MEN2 syndrome.

However, additional signs of neurofibromatosis type 1 are missing (e.g., café au lait spots, cutaneous neurofibromas, and Lisch nodules).

E) CORRECT:

Multiple endocrine neoplasia 2A and 2B (MEN 2A and MEN 2B) are caused by a germline mutation and lead to altered expression of the RET proto-oncogene. This patient's features of medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and primary hyperparathyroidism strongly suggest MEN 2A. Since MEN 2A and B are caused by an autosomal dominant gene mutation, all family members of this patient should be screened for the presence of the mutated gene.

Key learning point: Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A is caused by a germline mutation in the RET proto-oncogene and features medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and primary hyperparathyroidism.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs of medullary thyroid carcinoma (dysphagia, hoarseness, elevated calcitonin, irregular margins, and microcalcifications on neck ultrasonography), pheochromocytoma (throbbing headaches, diaphoresis, heart palpitations), and primary hyperparathyroidism (constipation, recurrent kidney stones, elevated calcium and ALP, decreased phosphorus). These features are suggestive of multiple endocrine neoplasia 2A (MEN 2A).

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 1-month history of a painless lump on his neck. He underwent adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma two years ago. On examination, there is a firm, irregular swelling on the right side of his neck. Ultrasonography of the thyroid gland reveals a 2-cm nodule with irregular margins and microcalcifications in the right thyroid lobe. Further evaluation is most likely to show an increased serum concentration of which one of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a malignant neoplasm of the parafollicular cells (C cells) that often arises sporadically but is also associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A and type 2B (MEN2). Since parafollicular cells produce the hormone calcitonin, increased serum calcitonin would be expected. Measuring the serum calcitonin concentration is helpful to support the diagnosis of medullary thyroid carcinoma and is also used to monitor for residual disease or recurrence after thyroidectomy.

Key learning point: Medullary thyroid carcinoma arises from parafollicular C cells and is characterized by elevated serum calcitonin, serving as a key tumor marker for diagnosis and monitoring.

B) INCORRECT:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma does not lead to increased serum TSH. Increased serum TSH can be seen in primary hypothyroidism or central hyperthyroidism. However, this patient has no symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., weight gain, constipation, fatigue) or hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, diarrhea, restlessness). Also, MEN2 is not commonly associated with dysfunction of the thyroid gland.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased serum PTH would indicate hyperparathyroidism, which is a feature of MEN2 A in 20–30% of cases. However, the patient shows no symptoms of hyperparathyroidism (e.g., nephrolithiasis, bone, muscle, and joint pain, peptic ulcer disease, or depression). Additionally, a firm, irregular thyroid nodule is more suggestive of a malignancy of the thyroid gland, which does not increase serum PTH.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased serum gastrin would be seen in gastrinoma, which is a feature of MEN1, not MEN2. MEN1 would also manifest with primary hyperparathyroidism and/or pituitary adenomas, not with pheochromocytoma. Furthermore, gastrinomas are located mainly in the duodenum or pancreas and would therefore neither cause a swelling on the right side of the neck nor a nodule in the thyroid lobe. Finally, symptoms of gastrinoma such as treatment-resistant peptic ulcer disease and diarrhea are not seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased serum metanephrines would be seen in pheochromocytoma, which is a feature of MEN2. However, the patient was already operated on for a pheochromocytoma, and the recent findings are consistent with medullary thyroid carcinoma, which would not result in an increase in serum metanephrines.
questions.hint: His painless, irregular thyroid nodule should raise concern for medullary thyroid carcinoma as a feature of MEN2 syndrome.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents for evaluation of a palpable neck mass she noticed two months ago. She reports intermittent episodes of palpitations, sweating, and severe headaches. She also mentions a history of recurrent kidney stones. Her father died at age 42 during a minor surgery due to what was described as a 'hypertensive crisis.' On examination, her blood pressure is 165/98 mmHg and her heart rate is 108/min. A firm, 2-cm nodule is palpated in the right lobe of her thyroid. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be identified in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The patient's episodic hypertension, palpitations, sweating, and headache strongly suggest a pheochromocytoma, which secretes catecholamines. Vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) is a metabolite of catecholamines. Therefore, a pheochromocytoma would cause an elevation, not a decrease, in urinary VMA or other metanephrines.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated thyrotropin (TSH) would indicate primary hypothyroidism. While hypothyroidism can cause a goiter, this patient's thyroid finding is a discrete nodule, and she lacks other symptoms of hypothyroidism. The type of thyroid cancer associated with her syndromic picture, medullary thyroid carcinoma, arises from parafollicular C-cells and is not TSH-dependent.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2A (MEN 2A), an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), pheochromocytoma, and primary hyperparathyroidism. MTC arises from the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid. These cells produce calcitonin, making it a highly specific tumor marker for MTC.

The episodic palpitations, sweating, headaches, and hypertension are due to a pheochromocytoma. The history of kidney stones suggests hypercalcemia from parathyroid hyperplasia.

D) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum cortisol is characteristic of Cushing syndrome, which can cause hypertension. However, this patient's constellation of symptoms, particularly the episodic nature of her spells (palpitations, sweating, headache), is classic for a pheochromocytoma. She lacks other stigmata of Cushing syndrome, such as central obesity, purple striae, or proximal muscle weakness. Furthermore, Cushing syndrome is not a component of the endocrine neoplasia syndrome suggested by her full clinical picture.
questions.hint: This patient's constellation of a thyroid nodule, symptoms suggestive of a pheochromocytoma, and a history of kidney stones points towards a specific familial syndrome.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of recurrent episodes of headaches, palpitations, and sweating. He was adopted shortly after birth and does not know his biological parents. His pulse is 103/min and blood pressure is 160/105 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple soft, yellow papules on the tip of the tongue. There is a 2-cm, firm thyroid nodule. He has long and slender upper extremities, and his elbows and knees can be hyperextended. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is a mutation in which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2, which includes MEN 2A and MEN 2B, results from a gain-of-function mutation of the RET gene. RET encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase that plays a key role in cell growth, differentiation, and survival. Medullary thyroid cancer (which develops in almost all patients) and pheochromocytoma are associated with both MEN 2A and MEN 2B. MEN 2A is associated with primary hyperparathyroidism, and MEN 2B is associated with marfanoid habitus and mucosal neuromas.

Early diagnosis of MEN 2-associated medullary thyroid cancer is essential because this malignancy is highly aggressive. High-risk patients identified by genetic screening should undergo thyroidectomy during the first year of life.

B) INCORRECT:

Mutations in the FBN1 gene result in a deficiency of fibrillin-1, which is the underlying cause of Marfan syndrome. This condition typically manifests with long extremities and joint hypermobility as seen in this patient but is not associated with pheochromocytoma, thyroid nodules, or mucosal neuromas. Moreover, patients with Marfan syndrome usually also have cardiovascular (e.g., aortic disease) and ophthalmologic symptoms (e.g, lens dislocation), which are not seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Mutations in the TSC2 tumor suppressor gene result in a deficiency of tuberin protein, which is the underlying cause of tuberous sclerosis. This condition typically manifests in childhood with ash-leaf spots, angiofibromas, Shagreen patches, and benign brain tumors (most commonly hamartomas). Most patients have intellectual disabilities and epilepsy. None of these features are seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Mutations in the COL5A1 gene result in faulty synthesis of type V collagen, which is the underlying cause of classical Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. This condition typically manifests with joint hypermobility as seen in this patient but is not associated with pheochromocytoma, thyroid nodules, or mucosal neuromas. Moreover, patients with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome usually also have skin hyperextensibility and abnormal wound healing, which are not seen in this patient.
Image Description:

The skin of the elbow is hyperelastic (cutis hyperelastica) due to impaired collagen synthesis.

This, along with joint hypermobility, is a characteristic feature of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Mutations in the MEN1 tumor suppressor gene result in inactivation of menin protein, which is the underlying cause of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1. This condition most commonly manifests with hyperparathyroidism and is associated with endocrine pancreatic tumors (e.g., gastrinoma, insulinoma), pituitary adenomas, and carcinoid tumors, none of which are seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Mutations in the NF1 tumor suppressor gene result in a deficiency of neurofibromin protein, which is the underlying cause of neurofibromatosis type I. This condition typically manifests with café-au-lait spots, Lisch nodules, and multiple cutaneous neurofibromas and optic gliomas, none of which are seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.
questions.hint: This man's paroxysmal headaches, palpitations, sweating, and hypertension are concerning for a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma. His long upper extremities and joint laxity are features of Marfanoid habitus. Together with the firm thyroid nodule (possibly thyroid cancer) and the soft, yellow papules on the tongue (likely mucosal neuromas), these findings raise suspicion for multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B).
